head.title: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?

hedline.hl1: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?

abstract.p: Kathleen Dillon letter responds to Fred Brock's July 2 Seniority column on advertising industry's targeting of young consumers, despite growing wealth and numbers of older consumers; points out that Modern Maturity magazine does not have subscribers per se, but has captive audience of AARP members (M)

block.p: In ''A Madison Avenue Fantasy,'' (Seniority, July 2), Fred Brock discussed the advertising industry's continuing emphasis on young consumers, despite the greater wealth and increasing numbers of older adults. The column drew varied responses from readers.

In ''A Madison Avenue Fantasy,'' (Seniority, July 2), Fred Brock discussed the advertising industry's continuing emphasis on young consumers, despite the greater wealth and increasing numbers of older adults. The column drew varied responses from readers.

The column was spot-on about the lack of advertising aimed at higher age groups, but its comparison of the ad pages of Modern Maturity with those of magazines like Fast Company or Red Herring is wide of the mark. Modern Maturity doesn't have subscribers as such: it has a captive audience of AARP members.

Take a look at the British magazine, The Oldie, which is aimed at us grown-ups, and compare its editorial content with that of Modern Maturity. I pay upwards of $60 a year to get The Oldie because it's interesting to read, it prints hackle-raising articles on politically incorrect topics, and the puzzles are challenging.
KATHLEEN DILLON New York City, July 2
